trial_identification.studytitle: Intravascular device administration sets: Replacement after Standard Versus Prolonged use (The RSVP Trial)
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Intravascular device (IVD) administration sets: a comparison of IVD-related Bloodstream Infection between Replacement after Standard Versus Prolonged use (The RSVP Trial)

conditions.healthcondition: Intravascular device related blood stream infection

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Studies of infection and infectious agents

interventions.interventions: Patients in this study have intravascular devices (IVDs) used in medical, surgical, intensive care, oncology and haematology units, and include adult and paediatric patients. Patients will have their administration set replaced every 4 days. This will continue for the course of their intravenous (IV) therapy.
interventions.comparator: Patients will have their intravascular devices replaced every 7 days for the course of their IV therapy.

primaryOutcome.outcome: IVD-related Bloodstream Infection (IVD-BSI): (1) Primary bacteraemia/fungaemia with >=1 positive blood culture from a peripheral vein with no other identifiable source for the BSI other than the IVD, plus, one of: a positive semiquantitative (>15cfu) device culture, with the same organism (species and antibiogram) isolated from the device and blood, or (2) Two blood cultures (one from an IVD hub and one from a peripheral vein), that both meet the CRBSI criteria for differential time to positivity (DTP) (growth of the same microbe from hub drawn blood at least 2 hours before growth from the peripheral blood)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: While IVD is in situ or within 48 hours of IVD removal

secondaryOutcome.outcome: (i) IVD Colonisation: Growth of >15 CFU from distal segment of IVD tip on removal, using the semiquantitative culture method
(ii) Administration set (AS) colonisation: Growth of 10^3 CFU/ml from infusate taken from the AS.
All cause BSI: Any positive blood culture result
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: While the IVD is in situ, or within 48 hours of removal.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: (iv) All cause mortality: Mortality at hospital discharge
(v) Time the IVD was in situ.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At the time of IVD removal.
Number of AS used from time of study entry to IVD removal

secondaryOutcome.outcome: (vii) Costs. AS consumable prices, staff time and treatment costs for IVD-BSI.

Possible CRBSI: One or more positive blood cultures drawn through two or more lumens of an IVD, where one of the blood cultures has a colony count at least 3-fold greater than the colony count for the blood culture obtained from the second lumen.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Whilst IVD in situ or within 48 hours of removal.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Infusate Related bloodstream Infection (IRBSI): Concordant growth of the same organism from the infusate and blood cultures with no other identifiable source of infection
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: While IVD is in situ or within 48 hours of removal

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1. Informed written consent or waived consent (as per approving HREC) 2. Central venous or peripheral arterial IVD in situ. 3. IVD and AS have been insitu for 72-95 hours 4. IVD scheduled/expected use > or =7 days
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Current bloodstream infection Planned removal of device less than or equal to 24 hours IVD in situ >96 hours Original AS already routinely replaced

trial_design.concealment: Computer generated allocation provided by electronic data collection device. Allocation is concealed until the patient is randomised

ethicsAndSummary.summary: IVD insertion is the most common invasive healthcare procedure with approximately 14 million IVDs used in Australia each year. IVDs alone are inadequate to deliver most therapy and require connection to an administration set. These IVD administration sets (AS) refer to infusion systems comprised of some or all of: tubing, fluid containers, pressure monitoring transducers, blood sampling ports, measuring burettes and extension tubing. IVDs and their AS break the natural defence barrier of the skin, and are the single most important cause of healthcare acquired blood stream infection (BSI). Most IVD's are replaced every 3 -4 days , however preliminary research suggests routine replacement of AS every 4 days costs Australia about $1 billion annually, and some studies suggest 7 day use would reduce costs with no threat to patient safety.
